images.caption: Figure 1:Comparison between UQ setups.Traditional LLM UQ (a) measures the uncertainty of an answer given a question, whereas the UQ for LLM reasoning (b) expands the problem by considering multi-step responses rather than a single response. Agent UQ (c) goes further by considering continual interactions between agent and user/environment across the trajectory, making it a multi-turn, interactive inference setup (example sourced fromτ\tau-bench Airline;barres2025tau).

Figure 2:Graphical model for an agent problem-solving trajectory with examples.Given a task specificationE0E_{0}and an initial user queryO0O_{0}, an agent spans a multi-turn trajectory characterized by a chain of actionAA, observationOO, and environment stateEE. This simple abstraction describes some representative agentic prompting methods such as ReAct[yao2022react]. See AppendixA.1for details.

Figure 3:Limitation of existing UQ (a) and our suggestion (b).Prior works just concern the evidentiality when designing or evaluating UQ while neglectinginteractivity, so they may fail to reliably capture the agent’s failure. We urge expanding a dimension of interest, interactivity, and moving on to reducible uncertainty modeling of agents.
